Award.AbstractNarration:
When do cartels form? What market conditions are conducive to cartel formation? How long do cartels last? In what markets can we expect cartels to persist for a long time? What are the implications of recessions for cartel activity? Are enforcement efforts, such as leniency programs, reducing the frequency of cartels? What new policies might prove effective?

This award funds research into these and other questions using a combination of research methods. The PI will use a stochastic dynamic model of the birth and death of cartels to analyze the possible determinants of cartel duration and the frequency of cartels in an economy. The PI will use this birth-death process to simulate a panel data set of industries that includes some endogenous cartelization. The simulation model will be used to identify improved methods for estimating the probability of detection through data on discovered cartels; to provide an ex ante evaluation of the performance of various competition policies; and finally to discover useful proxies for the latent cartel rate to improve the ex post evaluation of cartel policies.
The PI will also use qualitative research methods to develop new facts about cartel birth, death, and detection through the analysis of US and European cases and interviews with executives who have participated in cartel arrangements. The case analysis will better identify the true source of cartel detection. The interviews shed light on why firms chose to form a cartel and what caused it to break down.

Broader impacts are fully integrated into the research, because the research questions are driven in part by the challenges faced by competition and antitrust enforcement agencies. Deterring and ending cartels is good for consumers, but it is difficult to evaluate the full benefit of these policies from observations limited to the population of observed cartels. The combination of research methods here will allow the PI to develop new recommendations for competition authorities in the US and also around the globe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cartels cause great harm to society. Cartels stifle competition and ultimately result in consumers paying higher prices. This harm is particularly detrimental to the poor when collusion concerns basic products such as bread, gasoline, and housing. The social goal of this project was to reduce the presence of collusion in the U.S. and world economies by devising better methods for detecting cartels and improving policies for deterring their formation. More specifically, the project improved our understanding of how cartels behave (the more we know about cartels, the easier they are to detect) and how government policies impact cartels (the more we know about a policy’s efficacy, the more we know which policies to use). There were four specific contributions.

The first contribution is developing a better method for measuring how long cartels last. Existing methods are known to be biased because we do not observe all cartels, only those that are discovered. Due to our NSF-funded research, we can now say with greater confidence that cartels tend to last around six years on average, which is ample time to inflict considerable harm on consumers.

A second contribution is providing a better understanding about how the manner in which firms coordinate affects the effectiveness of collusion. More specifically, firms might raise prices through express communication (which is clearly unlawful) or signaling with their prices (which is lawful). Knowing the market structures for which express communication is required is useful for detecting collusion which can actually be prosecuted. Our experimental evidence showed that express communication becomes quite necessary when there are more two firms and firms are substantively different in their costs. Markets with two symmetric firms can be quite successful in colluding without illegal communication.

The third contribution is shedding new light on collusive practices that, while commonly used, are not well understood; in particular, a minimum recommended price (often put forth by a trade association) and coordination on list prices. A minimum recommended price was shown to be a very effective device for collusion when firms have very different costs or products. As to list prices, the phenomenon is that firms coordinated on list prices even though they generally offered discounts to customers (who are industrial buyers). How could collusion be effective when firms did not agree to the actual price charged? An explanation was developed which helps identify those markets for which coordination on list prices is likely to be effective.

The final contribution is investigating the efficacy of corporate leniency programs, which is arguably the most important development in anti-cartel policy in the last 25 years. While there is much to recommend those programs, our analysis found that a leniency program can, in some cases, result in more cartels. However, some complementary policy instruments are identified to make it far more likely that a leniency program has the intended effect of reducing the presence of cartels in an economy.
